statement:
If $U$ is the limit of a sequence $$u_1,\,u_2,\,u_3,\,\ldots$$ of real
or complex numbers, then $U$ can be expressed as the series sum
$$U = u_1+\sum_{i=1}^\infty(u_{i+1}-u_i).$$

[*Proof.*]{} Let
$\displaystyle s_n := u_1+\sum_{i=1}^{n-1}(u_{i+1}-u_i)$. We see that
$$s_n = u_1+\sum_{i=1}^{n-1}u_{i+1}-\sum_{i=1}^{n-1}u_i = u_1+\sum_{j=2}^nu_j-\sum_{i=1}^{n-1}u_i = u_n$$
for all $n = 1,\,2,\,3,\,\ldots$ Thus
$$u_1+\sum_{i=1}^\infty(u_{i+1}-u_i) = \lim_{n\to\infty}s_n = \lim_{n\to\infty}u_n = U,$$
Q.E.D.
names: limit of sequence as sum of series
